entries.question: For those of you leading high-growth startups, especially in industries where the regulatory landscape is still taking shape, how have you approached finding outside counsel or advisors who can help ensure your company’s ethical standards stay aligned with both your personal values and evolving legal requirements? I’m particularly interested in recommendations for folks who are pragmatic and can help foster a culture of transparency and integrity, not just check the compliance boxes. Thanks in advance!
entries.comprehensive_answer: A recurring theme across legal and business leadership is the critical importance of aligning personal and organizational ethics, especially when navigating ambiguous or rapidly evolving regulatory environments. Leaders must not only ensure their own ethical comfort but also foster a culture where transparency and integrity are prioritized, even when the law is unclear or evolving. This alignment is essential for both personal peace of mind and organizational resilience.

source_quotes.quoted_text: I was actually quite honored when they asked me to speak as part of this program. I mean, as a gc obviously you want to be constantly and consistently, if not the most ethical person in the room, part of the tone from the top, uh, kind of culture carrier with respect to high ethical standards at your organization. I think we have all seen firsthand too the pitfalls of having issues, um, even if unethical, improper inappropriate, that can create legal work for ourselves when that happens... you have to ask yourself, is this unethical? Is this in, in inappropriate, is this illegal? Or, you know, my question that I'm always asking myself, can I sleep at night? Can I sit across the table from a regulator with a straight face and articulate my position based on the precedent? 'cause there's nothing in the law about this.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: what's really steering my sort of ethical practice right now is commitment to my own sense of ethics coupled with an understanding of what the company's ethics and ethos are. And so you really have to deeply know who your company is, who it's made of, and what they believe and what their North Star orientation is. And also who you are, right? Like what, what are you comfortable with and what can you to, to Catherine's earlier point, what can you sleep at night with feeling very comfortable that you've done the right thing and that you can defend whatever positions you've taken.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

request_intent_category.description: Users seeking specific recommendations, referrals, or introductions to service providers, counsel, or vendors
examples: A friend is looking for recommendations for sell side counsel for a SaaS company going through an exit. Valuation will be between $2.5BN and $4BN. European based parent company, but SaaS entity is dual headquartered in Europe and U.S. Not just looking for all the usual suspects at the big firms, but someone who will really be pragmatic and efficient, and may consider an alternative fee arrangement.
Does anyone have a recommendation for a cost-effective firm to advise on the formation of a UK subsidiary for a private U.S. company? Any recommendations would be greatly appreciated!
We are looking for an Info Sec Consultant to advise us on leveling up our practices. (We're a fully remote tech start-up.) Any recommendations would be greatly appreciated.

request_specificity.description: Requests with very specific requirements, jurisdictions, practice areas, or detailed parameters
examples: I need a document notarized and apostilled for use in Bulgaria. In Austin, TX, we get this done at one of the UPS offices downtown, but I believe that UPS in Charlotte does not offer this service. Any referrals would be sincerely appreciated!
I'm looking for highly pragmatic and reasonably affordable employment counsel to help with a worker classification question in Poland. Does anybody have a recommendation? Thank you!
Can anybody recommend a good Plaintiff's Medical Malpractice attorney in the Houston Area? Asking for a family member who suffered from brain cancer. Thank you in advance.

user_persona.description: Users from startups or high-growth companies dealing with scaling challenges and emerging legal needs
examples: An industry colleague is looking for a lawyer with expertise/experience in drafting OMs and associated docs for a startup without having to pay big-firm fees. I'd appreciate your sharing any recommendations. Thank you.

I'm advising a startup that's aiming to launch its product on January 1 and we're currently exploring the best legal and strategic ways to lock in customers this fall/winter, before the product is fully live. I'd love to hear any suggestions or experiences with: * Early access agreements or pre-sale contracts * Letters of intent vs. binding agreements * Deferred billing models or refundable deposits * Legal considerations around offering discounts for early commitment * Common pitfalls or red flags you've seen Any frameworks, template clauses, or war stories would be hugely appreciated.
I'm looking for contingent search firms that have a strong track record placing senior technical leaders (CTO, VP/Head of Engineering) in early-stage or high-growth startups. Thank you in advance!

user_persona.description: Users from established, larger companies dealing with complex operational, compliance, and strategic issues
examples: For those who are permitting the use of GitHub Copilot: Have you opened it up to all areas of the codebase or are you limiting it to certain areas only (and if so, why)? In the process of developing a policy to set guardrails around its use, and I want to get an updated response on this question. This also assumes that appropriate restrictions will be put in place (use of the Enterprise License only, attribution requirements, duplication detection filter, human code review, etc.).

Hello everyone - curious if any legal departments have surveyed their outside counsel firms to get a read on exactly how they are using AI, what tools for which tasks, and documenting any client benefits (especially specific to your work)? Stats like this from a recent Axiom survey make me wonder. "With 79% of law firms using AI but only 6% passing savings to clients, in-house departments face a cruel irony: they must invest in AI capabilities while their outside counsel benefits from AI efficiencies without sharing cost savings."

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: Has anyone worked with a consultant or firm that specializes in building trust and transparency within legal or compliance teams, particularly to support both ethical practice and D&I initiatives? We're a mid-sized tech company looking for targeted recommendations—ideally someone who can help us implement open communication strategies and drive real buy-in across our teams. Any referrals or experiences would be much appreciated!
entries.comprehensive_answer: Building trust and transparency within organizations is a foundational strategy for both ethical legal practice and effective diversity and inclusion initiatives. Whether addressing ethical dilemmas or advancing D&I, leaders emphasize the need for open communication, relationship-building, and clear articulation of values to foster buy-in and accountability across teams.

source_quotes.quoted_text: from my perspective, the most important thing I do when I start a new role, um, is really to work on building those relationships and building trust within the organization, hopefully to keep, to keep my client from lying by omission, from not telling me the whole story. Things like that. Sometimes that works and sometimes that doesn't. Um, I've had, uh, a lot of luck cultivating that trust in the organization that I'm at now.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: by putting them together, everybody owns diversity. Everybody owns building an equitable workplace. And then you start creating a flywheel. And this is what we saw with women when I started. We saw really great talented women coming to Etsy naturally because of our brand. And we saw them inviting and, and bringing on other talented women. And we saw them building a workplace that was equitable based on gender, and it created a flywheel in which that was really successful. And so what we realized is that we needed to create a flywheel for everybody, and we needed to create a flywheel in which we were really addressing with data how to make Etsy a more diverse and inclusive workplace.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

I have an in-person training at the end of this month and I am looking for practical ideas that scale, stick, and actually make an impact on the front lines.

entries.question: For those leading legal or compliance functions at larger organizations: how are you approaching the evolving nature of ethical and compliance challenges, especially as technology and market dynamics shift? Would love to hear what frameworks, ongoing learning strategies, or scenario planning methods have actually helped your teams stay ahead—particularly in areas like AI, equity management, or board governance. Open to any best practices or lessons learned as we look to make our own approach more proactive and adaptable.
entries.comprehensive_answer: Legal and business leaders increasingly recognize that ethical and compliance challenges are not static but evolve with technological and market changes. This requires a proactive, adaptable approach—whether in AI adoption, equity management, or board governance—where continuous learning, scenario planning, and openness to new frameworks are essential for success.

source_quotes.quoted_text: One is it's constantly changing and it's complicated. And another, I think is it, this is not the easiest topic to discuss because oftentimes we might be afraid that we're not doing it right or that we got it wrong, right? And people don't love talking about those moments, especially when it comes to things like ethics. But Catherine, to the point you made, as long as we are sort of in the space of I believe that I'm doing the right thing, that goes a really long way.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: AI is moving way faster than a lot of legal teams are comfortable with, and prompting is the tip of that very powerful momentum. ... So now that AI is answering questions at scale, the stakes are really big and that's why today is about how we ask those questions better. So, um, we wanna use these tools, smart and safe.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

source_quotes.quoted_text: From and we're dealing with a bunch of the private company GCS now. In in my time. There's never been a more stressful time on the GC because of that time and what's happening and you see it in the news, but you have plans expiring RSU plans in particular. So you have this combination of pressure from the c-suite and the board not understanding. the ramifications in particular the massive accounting charges Are potentially coming depending on how you maneuver and then you have the pressure of all of the employees and the combination of of those as is is the job of the GC now to juggle...
source_quotes.transcript_title: Laying the Groundwork - Employee & Early Shareholder Equity Best Practices (Louisa Daniels, Recursion; Jeff Le Sage, Liquid Stock)

entries.comprehensive_answer: Effective legal and business leadership requires not only technical expertise but also the humility to recognize knowledge gaps and seek outside counsel or specialized tools when necessary. This principle is echoed in both ethical legal practice and the responsible adoption of AI, where overconfidence can lead to significant risk, and self-awareness is a safeguard.

source_quotes.quoted_text: So with those types of issues, per maybe it is arguably unethical to give advice to your client, to your organization if you really have no idea what you're talking about. So you have to assess your own standards and your own comfort level in terms of what you're willing to teach yourself or learn versus what you're willing to say, no, I need to put my foot down. I need to talk to outside counsel. I need additional resources.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: That's somewhat that, that, that's a big problem. If you don't have a bit of a BS meter on the topic in question, you can't really know it's wrong. So you have to view it as sort of a Google something that helps you figure out what you don't know. And if it's important enough or risky enough, you'd then have to escalate it to somebody who does Trust but verify Trust, but verify
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

request_intent_category.description: Users seeking specific recommendations, referrals, or introductions to service providers, counsel, or vendors
examples: A friend is looking for recommendations for sell side counsel for a SaaS company going through an exit. Valuation will be between $2.5BN and $4BN. European based parent company, but SaaS entity is dual headquartered in Europe and U.S. Not just looking for all the usual suspects at the big firms, but someone who will really be pragmatic and efficient, and may consider an alternative fee arrangement.
Does anyone have a recommendation for a cost-effective firm to advise on the formation of a UK subsidiary for a private U.S. company? Any recommendations would be greatly appreciated!
We are looking for an Info Sec Consultant to advise us on leveling up our practices. (We're a fully remote tech start-up.) Any recommendations would be greatly appreciated.

request_specificity.description: Complex requests involving multiple jurisdictions, practice areas, or interconnected requirements
examples: What have other multi-national employers done with respect to ex-US employees participating in corporate bonus programs? So far, we do not have employees eligible for a new corporate bonus program outside of the U.S. (it's only for VP+ employees) but the bonus program will likely expand over time. Our global employment counsel has advised either globalizing the bonus plan (similar to what we have done for our commission plan), add country-specific riders, or fully and expressly incorporate the bonus terms into the contracts rather than referencing the standalone program document. Curious to learn what your experience has been and any lessons learned.

We're a SaaS company that primarily sells in the US, Canada, UK, and EU. We have had sellers bring forward prospects from countries outside of that list, but it's been on a very ad hoc basis, so we're trying to put together a plan regarding how to best handle selling into a new country. I'm curious if anyone has experience with putting together such a plan or if anyone can share some sample documentation.

We're looking to benchmark how tech companies with operations in UK and Germany are handling time tracking for non-hourly employees to comply with working time regulations in those regions. Any feedback from a best practices and ease of administration perspective would be greatly appreciated!

user_persona.description: Users from startups or high-growth companies dealing with scaling challenges and emerging legal needs
examples: An industry colleague is looking for a lawyer with expertise/experience in drafting OMs and associated docs for a startup without having to pay big-firm fees. I'd appreciate your sharing any recommendations. Thank you.

I'm advising a startup that's aiming to launch its product on January 1 and we're currently exploring the best legal and strategic ways to lock in customers this fall/winter, before the product is fully live. I'd love to hear any suggestions or experiences with: * Early access agreements or pre-sale contracts * Letters of intent vs. binding agreements * Deferred billing models or refundable deposits * Legal considerations around offering discounts for early commitment * Common pitfalls or red flags you've seen Any frameworks, template clauses, or war stories would be hugely appreciated.
I'm looking for contingent search firms that have a strong track record placing senior technical leaders (CTO, VP/Head of Engineering) in early-stage or high-growth startups. Thank you in advance!

user_persona.description: Users from established, larger companies dealing with complex operational, compliance, and strategic issues
examples: For those who are permitting the use of GitHub Copilot: Have you opened it up to all areas of the codebase or are you limiting it to certain areas only (and if so, why)? Hello everyone - curious if any legal departments have surveyed their outside counsel firms to get a read on exactly how they are using AI, what tools for which tasks, and documenting any client benefits (especially specific to your work)? Stats like this from a recent Axiom survey make me wonder. "With 79% of law firms using AI but only 6% passing savings to clients, in-house departments face a cruel irony: they must invest in AI capabilities while their outside counsel benefits from AI efficiencies without sharing cost savings."

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: For those of you in highly regulated industries (think fintech, healthtech, etc.), have you worked with any consultants or firms that specialize in helping companies navigate regulatory uncertainty—particularly when it comes to building trust with both internal teams and external stakeholders? We’re looking for recommendations on partners who really understand the importance of transparency and radical honesty, and can help us position ourselves as a credible, proactive player with regulators and the public. Any referrals or lessons learned would be much appreciated!
entries.comprehensive_answer: Transparency and radical honesty with both internal and external stakeholders are vital for managing regulatory risk and maintaining organizational credibility, especially in industries facing regulatory uncertainty or public scrutiny. This approach not only builds trust but also positions the organization as a 'good actor' in the eyes of regulators, partners, and the public.

source_quotes.quoted_text: I've always been radically transparent with the crypto regulatory environment. I have a lot of discussion with the board, my boards, um, to make sure that they feel comfortable that, you know, our strategy is well in hand. ... So I think you have to be radically transparent, both with your governance, but also with your business. ... So you, the transparency and ensuring that you have this under control. We're not gonna, like, legal is not gonna bless anything by the business that we don't have a response to. We don't have a strategy, we don't feel okay with.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: we have, uh, a generous parental leave, uh, six months, uh, of paid leave, which I think is probably industry leading. ... we've done pay equity studies and we share the results with our board and publicly and with our employees. ... we've done a lot of things that really have focused on, uh, gender equity. And as a result, um, we've really built a company that is a pretty, um, gender balanced workplace.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

examples: Looking for the latest on what people are seeing as market when it comes to big law firm discounts, both for private company and venture fund clients. Are your discounts time bound? What ranges are you getting these days? Thank you.

Curious to hear how companies subject to CA SB 261's requirement to release a report detailing climate related financial risk by 1/1/2026 are going about preparing that report. I'm specifically interested in hearing whether folks have engaged an outside firm (e.g., KPMG, Watershed, S&P, law firms, etc.) to conduct a climate risk assessment as an input to that report (and to ultimately produce that report in whatever format CA will require).

Has anyone here adopted a practice of skipping the formal PIP process and moving directly to a severance offer for under-performers? Or, are any of you aware of any late-stage private tech companies who have implemented this approach (i.e. not Apple, Meta, Amazon, which follow a similar approach)? Specifically, I'd love to know: * Are you seeing this trend in your networks, and if so, how is it working in practice? * What pitfalls have you encountered (beyond the obvious need for solid documentation and legal review of terminations)? * Any practical tips for managing risk or handling edge cases that aren't obvious from the outside? Would appreciate any real-world examples or lessons learned--especially from companies that don't have the litigation budgets of the public tech giants. Thanks.

Specifically, are you finding that your role is shifting more toward business advisor versus technical legal expert, and if so, how are you balancing risk, compliance, and organizational values in your decision-making? Would love to hear any practical frameworks or lessons learned from others navigating this shift.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The integration of legal, ethical, and business considerations is increasingly necessary as organizations face complex, cross-functional challenges—such as equity management, AI adoption, and D&I. Legal leaders are expected to act as both technical experts and business advisors, requiring them to balance risk, compliance, and organizational values in decision-making.

source_quotes.quoted_text: when you're in-house, you're kind of acting at, in a dual attorney and a business advisor role that you have to kind of walk a fine line. So I'm, I'm anxious to dig in and, and participate in today's conversation.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: Legal and business leaders increasingly recognize that ethical and compliance challenges are not static but evolve with technological and market changes. This requires a proactive, adaptable approach—whether in AI adoption, equity management, or board governance—where continuous learning, scenario planning, and openness to new frameworks are essential for success.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

source_quotes.quoted_text: I was also a partner Gibson done where I practice Securities m&a venture capital for 15 years. I've seen it. I've been through both sides now both sides. source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: For those of you leading legal ops or privacy teams at mid-to-large tech companies, how are you approaching responsible AI use within your legal function? Specifically, what internal guardrails or policies have you put in place to ensure confidentiality, privilege, and data security as AI tools become more embedded in your workflows? Would love to hear what’s worked (or hasn’t), and any practical tips for training teams on prompt crafting and output verification.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The responsible use of AI in legal practice requires a combination of technical acumen, critical thinking, and robust internal guardrails. Legal teams must not only understand how to craft effective prompts and verify outputs but also implement policies to protect confidentiality, privilege, and data security, especially as AI tools become more integrated into daily workflows.

source_quotes.quoted_text: AI is moving way faster than a lot of legal teams are comfortable with, and prompting is the tip of that very powerful momentum. ... So now that AI is answering questions at scale, the stakes are really big and that's why today is about how we ask those questions better. So, um, we wanna use these tools, smart and safe.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

source_quotes.quoted_text: one of the guardrails that my team, uh, is a bare minimum is that if we're using a public tool like chat GPT or anthropic to always, um, obs obfuscate the like client or the company information. So use Acme Co instead of Jasper. Uh, the tools like White Shoe and GC AI do this naturally. They like encrypt data in transit at rest and white shoe even like hashes it so that the LILM isn't even seeing like only the user's able to see it. Um, so those types of things get me comfortable that one, you're not sacrificing attorney-client privilege, but then two, like the only person who's ever gonna see the actual company information is, um, is yourself.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

entries.question: For those at larger organizations who have started integrating diversity, inclusion, and broader impact metrics into core business reporting (e.g., annual reports or 10-Ks), how are you structuring these disclosures to drive real accountability and shared ownership across the business? Would love to hear any lessons learned or best practices—especially around setting public goals and ensuring these initiatives are more than just a box-checking exercise.
entries.comprehensive_answer: Measuring, reporting, and setting public goals are powerful tools for driving accountability and progress in both diversity and inclusion and broader impact initiatives. When organizations integrate these metrics into their core business reporting, such as annual reports or 10-K filings, they create shared ownership and a culture where everyone is responsible for outcomes.

source_quotes.quoted_text: measuring, measuring has really been the key to all of this. Um, we have set all of our impact goals, um, publicly. We've shared them with all of our employees. We've shared them with the board. And then this past year, we took the step of having a, uh, integrated annual report. This means that we have put all our goals into our 10 k, our filing with the SEC. Now, before we did that, I said, you know, listen, I'm not going to be endorsing this if we are not sure that these numbers are real. And so we hired KPMG to help us audit our numbers. Um, and we, we disclose all of our stats. Um, and let me tell you, everybody feels ownership of that, just like they feel ownership. And when I said that this was really integrated with our business and part of the flywheel, people feel ownership of this as part of the results of the company. Everybody owns diversity.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

source_quotes.quoted_text: And what we are viewing it as is a flywheel. Because if we don't have a diverse workplace, if we're not hiring vendors that support our values, if we're, if we're, if we're polluting all over the place, if we're not rewarding fairly and equitably, then we're not creating a business that's sustainable. And by putting them together, everybody owns diversity. Everybody owns building an equitable workplace. And then you start creating a flywheel.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

Our global employment counsel has advised either globalizing the bonus plan (similar to what we have done for our commission plan), add country-specific riders, or fully and expressly incorporate the bonus terms into the contracts rather than referencing the standalone program document. Curious to learn what your experience has been and any lessons learned.

We're a SaaS company that primarily sells in the US, Canada, UK, and EU. We have had sellers bring forward prospects from countries outside of that list, but it's been on a very ad hoc basis, so we're trying to put together a plan regarding how to best handle selling into a new country. I'm curious if anyone has experience with putting together such a plan or if anyone can share some sample documentation.

We're looking to benchmark how tech companies with operations in UK and Germany are handling time tracking for non-hourly employees to comply with working time regulations in those regions. Any feedback from a best practices and ease of administration perspective would be greatly appreciated!

entries.question: For those of you at growth-stage companies who have started to outgrow founder-led board structures, how did you approach the transition to a more formal, independent board? Specifically, I'd love to hear about timing, recruiting independent directors, and any lessons learned around putting formal controls in place as you prepped for a potential exit or IPO. Any frameworks, pitfalls, or practical tips would be hugely appreciated!
entries.comprehensive_answer: The evolution of board governance from informal, founder-driven decision-making to professionalized, independent oversight is a critical transition for growing companies, especially those preparing for IPO or acquisition. This shift requires intentional planning, early recruitment of independent directors, and the gradual implementation of formal controls and processes.

source_quotes.quoted_text: you start out as a, a newly formed company with a founder, two founders, they're on the board, and, and there's a first step which involves some level of giving up control, right? And that's a, that's a big moment. You take money from someone outside, um, your board immediately changes. It's not just your company anymore. You've gotta, um, even if it, even if they don't have control of the board, most things are done by consensus at that level. And you need to bring someone along with you, you need to report to them. So board meetings become professionalized. You're, um, you're preparing materials in advance, you're taking criticism and input.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

source_quotes.quoted_text: I joined, uh, a couple weeks after a series B, and we immediately launched into an IPO, which closed, uh, 90 days after that. So in my first 120 days an IPO, that was interesting. ... And since then we've gone on to get our first trial into the clinic and also do a follow on financing, uh, even before S3 eligibility. So it's been a busy and eventful year.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: Has anyone successfully embedded diversity and inclusion initiatives into their core business strategy (as opposed to running them as standalone programs)? We’re a mid-sized tech company and our leadership is pushing for a more integrated approach, but we’re struggling to get traction beyond gender diversity. Would love to hear from anyone who’s seen a ‘flywheel effect’—where progress in one area helps drive broader change—and how you made that happen culturally and operationally. Thanks in advance!
entries.comprehensive_answer: Diversity and inclusion efforts are most effective when they are integrated into the core business strategy and culture, rather than treated as siloed or secondary initiatives. This integration creates a 'flywheel effect,' where progress in one area (e.g., gender diversity) accelerates broader organizational change and sustainability.

source_quotes.quoted_text: So really what we're talking about, when you take three impact goals and you say they're not separate from your business, when you say they're part of your overall business initiative, then you're talking about integrating impact, social impact into your business model. And what we are viewing it as is a flywheel. Because if we don't have a diverse workplace, if we're not hiring vendors that support our values, if we're, if we're, if we're polluting all over the place, if we're not rewarding fairly and equitably, then we're not creating a business that's sustainable. And by putting them together, everybody owns diversity. Everybody owns building an equitable workplace. And then you start creating a flywheel.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

source_quotes.quoted_text: And so what we realized is that we needed to create a flywheel for everybody, and we needed to create a flywheel in which we were really addressing with data how to make Etsy a more diverse and inclusive workplace. So this is Etsy's, uh, diversity goal to enable equitable access to the opportunities that we create. It's a pretty broad goal. And we decided that was really our overarching longer term goal, but specifically, we set three sub goals. I don't know if you can see that, but, um, they're around employees, vendors, and the marketplace. And they're really specific goals for employees. We wanted to double the percentage of black, black and Latinx employees and NCS workforce by 2023 for vendors. We wanted to focus more on, um, equitable and sustainable vendors. ... And in our marketplace, we wanted to be more inclusive and welcoming.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

entries.question: For those at larger organizations who are actively rolling out AI tools across legal or business ops: how are you thinking about upskilling your teams to keep pace with the shift in required skillsets? Specifically, are you focusing on prompt engineering, critical review of AI outputs, or training folks to use specialized tools? Would love to hear what’s worked (or hasn’t) in balancing tech adoption with maintaining strong human oversight and domain expertise—especially as we try to drive efficiency without sacrificing quality or increasing risk.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The adoption of AI and other advanced technologies in legal and business operations is driving a shift in skillsets, with an emphasis on prompt engineering, critical evaluation of outputs, and the ability to leverage specialized tools for efficiency and cost savings. However, human oversight and domain expertise remain indispensable for ensuring quality and mitigating risk.

source_quotes.quoted_text: The framework I think about for creating prompts is entirely stolen from, um, a book that came out last year by Ethan Molik, he's a researcher at, and the book's title co intelligence. ... But one of the things he talks about in terms of crafting good prompts to have the best re responses from AI is to give it first a role to play. So in the legal context, um, having it, telling it to act as an attorney and not just any attorney, but trying to narrow down on the specific expertise you're wanting it to have. Um, and that substantially improves prompts and you can just put that in the beginning of the prompt or, or bury it in the system prompt
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

source_quotes.quoted_text: I recently maybe two months ago closed an m and a transaction just by myself using AI tools opposite a full Kirkland and Alice bench. So that is not something I could do unassisted by ai. I probably saved, it wasn't the biggest transaction, it might have cost $30,000 through big law or $15,000 through medium law service providers, but it's really nice to be able to just internalize things like that. AI assisted,
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

source_quotes.quoted_text: Certainly if you don't have the expertise to run a certain kind of transaction or process, AI won't give you that expertise, but if you do, it's a very good resource. That's right. And we've all been saying, yeah.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

entries.question: We're a growth-stage company that's about to go through a significant board transition and are also considering some changes to our equity plan, which may impact a number of team members. For those who have managed similar multi-faceted organizational changes—especially where there are both legal and people implications—how have you approached the emotional and ethical challenges with your teams? Any frameworks or best practices for communicating these changes empathetically and maintaining trust during the process would be hugely appreciated. Bonus points if you have experience balancing fairness with long-term company health in these situations.
entries.comprehensive_answer: Legal and business leaders must be prepared to address the human side of organizational change, including the emotional and ethical challenges of board transitions, layoffs, or equity plan modifications. Successful navigation of these moments requires empathy, clear communication, and a focus on fairness and long-term organizational health.

source_quotes.quoted_text: I think your, uh, example about being ethical at a holiday party is the perfect one. I, a little anecdote from a, a company trip, um, that I was on earlier in the spring, um, one of our executive leaders, um, came to the table we were sitting at, it was that we were at dinner, everybody was having fun. Um, but, you know, I was sitting with the legal and compliance team and we were very quiet. Um, and the, the reaction was, you guys are the most boring people here. And it was like, thank you. I, I'll take that as a compliment because, um, it'll be really hard for me to be taken seriously and to be, um, perceived as doing my job. Well, if I'm the rowdiest most, most, uh, you know, outgoing person in the room, I I'll take being the most boring person at a party any day. Um, if it's a professional function, right? Um, I think that, that, I think that's important.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: I do think that having gone through two, my last two companies went public with me joining sort of midstream in one and just prior for the other. And I can certainly tell you that the board's sense of, you know, the urgency around this was not as high as it probably ought to have been, at least in one of those two companies. And you're then playing catch up, right? You're, you're sort of being like, well, we'll get questionnaires and we'll see who qualifies. Like that's not a great place to be. So it, it's definitely a challenge. I do think that Kat's point though about the competition is exceedingly important, right? You know, I don't know how many folks in this group have some form of a board search, either active or thinking about it or sort of socializing it, but finding the right fit people for these roles is really hard. And if you also are trying to check the boxes on some of these important diversity rules, which are becoming effective for most of us in the next year or two, it's gonna be really challenging. And, and I think it's great that we're pushing companies to move in this direction, but we're all competing for the same talent.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

In the process of developing a policy to set guardrails around its use, and I want to get an updated response on this question. This also assumes that appropriate restrictions will be put in place (use of the Enterprise License only, attribution requirements, duplication detection filter, human code review, etc.).

Hello everyone - curious if any legal departments have surveyed their outside counsel firms to get a read on exactly how they are using AI, what tools for which tasks, and documenting any client benefits (especially specific to your work)? Stats like this from a recent Axiom survey make me wonder. "With 79% of law firms using AI but only 6% passing savings to clients, in-house departments face a cruel irony: they must invest in AI capabilities while their outside counsel benefits from AI efficiencies without sharing cost savings."

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: For those of you leading legal or compliance teams at mid-sized tech companies, how have you successfully embedded your function within the business to encourage early issue reporting and build trust, especially across multiple jurisdictions or business units? We’re looking to move beyond the traditional 'enforcer' role and would love to hear what’s worked (or not) in making your team more visible and approachable. Any practical tips or lessons learned would be much appreciated!
entries.comprehensive_answer: A pattern across transcripts is the recognition that legal and compliance functions are most effective when they are visible, approachable, and embedded within the business. This presence encourages early reporting of issues, fosters a culture of integrity, and enables legal teams to act as trusted advisors rather than mere enforcers.

source_quotes.quoted_text: the approachability factor, especially in high growth tech companies, I think really cannot be overestimated. It is so important to be a visible person within your organization as a gc or for your, the rest of your legal team to be highly visible and to be present means that people are gonna come to you when they are concerned. When they have a fear about, like, actually, I don't know if what we did over here was totally right. And I think the person I wanna talk to is Catherine Orelia or Jasmine or whoever. ... I am everywhere all at once. Like I, Catherine, I follow your suit, I present at all hands. I, I attend some team meetings. I have one-on-one with staff level engineers on a regular basis, just so I can be like, Hey, what's the pulse? What's going on? Tell me about the business. Same thing with my sales team folks.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: And we started inviting people from different areas, people, people who are engineers, people in hr, people in marketing. And we started presenting a more diverse portfolio of our employees. How diverse is your brand? What are your ads look like? Who is in them? We have employee resource groups. We had, we, we turned to them and we said, how do you think we should diver, uh, diversify our employee population? They had a lot of great ideas. They started attending job fairs. One of the little caveats with that is that you need to be really, really conscious about not relying too much on your ERGs because they have a full-time job and they really wanna be on the track of being an engineer. They don't wanna become a, a second shift HR person and a recruiter. ... We offer referral bonuses and we measure, measure, measure. There is weekly reporting on diversity, hiring statistics, um, to the executive team. That's a lot of focus. And when you measure something, it moves.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

entries.question: For those leading legal departments at larger organizations: As the regulatory and business landscape gets more complex, how are you deciding when to keep work in-house versus bringing in outside counsel, consultants, or even AI solutions for highly specialized or high-stakes matters? We’re finding it increasingly difficult to strike the right balance between maintaining control and tapping into external expertise, especially as new issues keep emerging. Would love to hear how others are approaching this.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The increasing complexity of legal, regulatory, and business environments is driving a trend toward specialization and the use of external experts or technology solutions. Leaders must balance the desire for in-house control with the practical need to leverage outside counsel, consultants, or AI tools for specialized tasks, especially in high-stakes or novel situations.

source_quotes.quoted_text: So if it's something that, you know, I could do a little bit of legal research on and feel convicted that, hey, this is the right answer, and I, I would've spent a couple hours doing that work, I will do that all day. But I think that there's also, as a, as an advisor to the business, right, there's an opportunity cost in me spending all of that time researching the topic and getting the knowledge. And so I kind of, I try to position it in such a way of like, Hey, this is not my area of expertise. I think it would be best for the organization, and we'll actually probably save some money if we can just go to an expert in this topic Mm-Hmm. Um, get the quick answer, and then we can kind of decide from there.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

This also assumes that appropriate restrictions will be put in place (use of the Enterprise License only, attribution requirements, duplication detection filter, human code review, etc.).

Hello everyone - curious if any legal departments have surveyed their outside counsel firms to get a read on exactly how they are using AI, what tools for which tasks, and documenting any client benefits (especially specific to your work)? Stats like this from a recent Axiom survey make me wonder. "With 79% of law firms using AI but only 6% passing savings to clients, in-house departments face a cruel irony: they must invest in AI capabilities while their outside counsel benefits from AI efficiencies without sharing cost savings."

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: Has anyone found a good balance between keeping specialized legal or compliance work in-house versus bringing in external experts or tech solutions? We're a mid-sized fintech company facing increasingly complex regulatory requirements, and I'm interested in hearing how others in similar roles have approached this—especially when it comes to high-stakes or novel issues. Any recommendations or lessons learned would be much appreciated!
entries.comprehensive_answer: The increasing complexity of legal, regulatory, and business environments is driving a trend toward specialization and the use of external experts or technology solutions. Leaders must balance the desire for in-house control with the practical need to leverage outside counsel, consultants, or AI tools for specialized tasks, especially in high-stakes or novel situations.

source_quotes.quoted_text: So if it's something that, you know, I could do a little bit of legal research on and feel convicted that, hey, this is the right answer, and I, I would've spent a couple hours doing that work, I will do that all day. But I think that there's also, as a, as an advisor to the business, right, there's an opportunity cost in me spending all of that time researching the topic and getting the knowledge. And so I kind of, I try to position it in such a way of like, Hey, this is not my area of expertise. I think it would be best for the organization, and we'll actually probably save some money if we can just go to an expert in this topic Mm-Hmm. Um, get the quick answer, and then we can kind of decide from there.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: Legal and business leaders must be prepared to address the human side of organizational change, including the emotional and ethical challenges of board transitions, layoffs, or equity plan modifications. Successful navigation of these moments requires empathy, clear communication, and a focus on fairness and long-term organizational health.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

entries.question: For those of you at growth-stage companies, how are you thinking about the role of legal and business leadership in shaping company culture—especially when it comes to driving ethical conduct and DEI? Are there any practical approaches or frameworks you’ve found effective for setting the right tone from the top, beyond just formal policies? Would love to hear what’s worked (or hasn’t) as you’ve scaled.
entries.comprehensive_answer: A cross-cutting insight is that legal and business leaders are increasingly expected to act as culture carriers, setting the tone for ethical conduct, diversity, and inclusion from the top. This 'tone from the top' is reinforced through both formal policies and informal behaviors, and is essential for building trust and credibility throughout the organization.

source_quotes.quoted_text: I mean, as a gc obviously you want to be constantly and consistently, if not the most ethical person in the room, part of the tone from the top, uh, kind of culture carrier with respect to high ethical standards at your organization. I think we have all seen firsthand too the pitfalls of having issues, um, even if unethical, improper inappropriate, that can create legal work for ourselves when that happens.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: Second tone from the top, and this is twofold. One, ensure that your organization's CEO makes this a non-negotiable. If it isn't, well that's just kind of a problem generally, and there's, it's really hard to change that, I'll just say. So maybe that's something you think about long term as you contemplate a longer term move. But two, even if your CEO is a good person, make sure he is vocally supporting legal and compliance and vocally ensuring like, we have zero tolerance for X, Y, Z, um, and make sure he or she communicates that loudly and frequently. Mm-Hmm. And then secondarily, you and your legal team and your compliance team should really be living and breathing, breathing best practices of ethical conduct.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

entries.question: For those who've helped scale board governance in high-growth or evolving organizations: how have you approached professionalizing the board without stifling company culture or agility? I'm especially interested in any frameworks, incremental steps, or best practices you've found effective for introducing more formal controls (like delegation of authority, competency matrices, etc.) as the company matures. Would love to hear what worked (or didn't) and how you balanced structure with flexibility.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The process of professionalizing board governance is iterative and context-dependent, requiring a balance between formal controls and the unique culture and needs of the organization. There is no one-size-fits-all playbook; instead, leaders must incrementally introduce structures such as delegation of authority, competency matrices, and secure information flows, adapting as the company grows and circumstances change.

source_quotes.quoted_text: Yeah. I, I think it's incremental change, right? I mean, so I do see I'm maybe guilty of being part of a fancy schmancy law firm. Um, I, a lot of my clients are pure startups. They evolve exactly the way you're describing. And you know, I, I don't think you can, you can jump in at a series A round with one angel investor or you know, super angel or something and, and try and establish public company controls and procedures. But I think you want to see, um, the, the board governance process making progress along the way, right? So pick your battles, um, what's important, where, where, where is my, where are my biggest risks or where are decisions getting made that are outside of the eye shot of the board and that's gonna create a problem. And how do I start to channel that into board channels, um, and accept the fact that it's, you know, you can't boil the ocean and you can't change it overnight. ... but I think in general, as you evolve, you, it can't be a sudden last minute thing that, you know, you've, um, you've grown all the way from zero to 60 miles an hour without doing it and then suddenly, you know, turn it on. So I, I think you just make progress along the way.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

source_quotes.quoted_text: And those tend to be easy to pick out because they're the things that would require board approval anyway, like putting in place a loan facility of a certain size, right? You're gonna go to the board doing an acquisition of a certain size, like those kinds of things. Like, that's like the sleeve. I'm happy to give that to the board, you know, a commercial agreement that's 4 million in spend, but it's in budget, you know, I don't think you should have to go to board for that.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

entries.question: For those leading legal or compliance functions at larger organizations: How do you navigate situations where business units push for more aggressive risk-taking, especially when external benchmarks or peer practices are cited, but you feel there are ethical or legal boundaries that shouldn't be crossed? I'm interested in any frameworks or approaches you've found effective for balancing risk tolerance with maintaining non-negotiable standards, particularly when you're under pressure to be less 'risk averse.'
entries.comprehensive_answer: A recurring challenge in both legal and business contexts is managing the tension between risk tolerance and ethical obligations. Leaders must distinguish between being 'risk averse' and upholding non-negotiable ethical or legal standards, especially when pressured by business units or external comparisons.

source_quotes.quoted_text: And navigating that ethical quandary and sort of demonstrating that this is not necessarily about risk tolerance. It's about, you know, what you like commitment to upholding the law. And sometimes I feel like that gets thrown into the mix as like, oh, we're being too risk averse. And I like to remind folks like, it is not risk averse to uphold your ethical obligation to comply with loss. Right. Um, and in, in moments there may be some stretch, there may be some interpretation, there may be some challenge, especially in unregulated areas. Right.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: I think the first thing I always do is assess a spectrum of risk. You know, like with respect to looking at crypto, I always say that there's three big areas of risk. One is kind of technical hack, um, integrity, like, or your smart contracts good. Is your code good? Like obviously there's massive issues. There is, are your privacy incident response areas great. You know, you don't mess with that because like, again, that's, that's pretty existential and easy to fill a gap. Two criminal also something you don't mess with. You know, do you have, uh, A-M-L-K-Y-C sanctions in place? If you don't, you better have a darn good reason why you don't. If you're dealing with flow of funds, like, is your position justi justifiable with respect to, you know, are you, you know, theoretically helping a flow of dirty money? And this could be considered a national security risk. Like how are you dealing with that? You need to have an answer to that, and it needs to be a very good one. The third one, regulatory, like civil regulators, cryptos, it's no, no, uh, no secret that cryptos parts of crypto are kind of at war with the SEC. Well, how, how is that? Okay. How can you be at war with your regulator, if not your current regulator, if your unregulated potentially your future regulator with respect to your posture with the CFTC or the SEC?
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

So far, we do not have employees eligible for a new corporate bonus program outside of the U.S. (it's only for VP+ employees) but the bonus program will likely expand over time. Our global employment counsel has advised either globalizing the bonus plan (similar to what we have done for our commission plan), add country-specific riders, or fully and expressly incorporate the bonus terms into the contracts rather than referencing the standalone program document. Curious to learn what your experience has been and any lessons learned.

We're a SaaS company that primarily sells in the US, Canada, UK, and EU. We have had sellers bring forward prospects from countries outside of that list, but it's been on a very ad hoc basis, so we're trying to put together a plan regarding how to best handle selling into a new country. I'm curious if anyone has experience with putting together such a plan or if anyone can share some sample documentation.

We're looking to benchmark how tech companies with operations in UK and Germany are handling time tracking for non-hourly employees to comply with working time regulations in those regions. Any feedback from a best practices and ease of administration perspective would be greatly appreciated!

user_persona.description: Users from established, larger companies dealing with complex operational, compliance, and strategic issues
examples: For those who are permitting the use of GitHub Copilot: Have you opened it up to all areas of the codebase or are you limiting it to certain areas only (and if so, why)? In the process of developing a policy to set guardrails around its use, and I want to get an updated response on this question. This also assumes that appropriate restrictions will be put in place (use of the Enterprise License only, attribution requirements, duplication detection filter, human code review, etc.).

Hello everyone - curious if any legal departments have surveyed their outside counsel firms to get a read on exactly how they are using AI, what tools for which tasks, and documenting any client benefits (especially specific to your work)? Stats like this from a recent Axiom survey make me wonder. "With 79% of law firms using AI but only 6% passing savings to clients, in-house departments face a cruel irony: they must invest in AI capabilities while their outside counsel benefits from AI efficiencies without sharing cost savings."

Hi everyone, I'm looking to better understand how other legal departments manage budgeting for outside counsel spend, particularly for ongoing or unanticipated matters. Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?

entries.question: For those in legal or compliance roles at global tech companies, how have you navigated situations where business leadership pushes for more risk-taking, but you feel there are ethical or legal lines that can't be crossed? I'm especially interested in practical strategies for communicating the difference between being risk averse and upholding non-negotiable standards, particularly when facing pressure from business units or external benchmarks. Any recommendations or frameworks you've found effective would be greatly appreciated!
entries.comprehensive_answer: A recurring challenge in both legal and business contexts is managing the tension between risk tolerance and ethical obligations. Leaders must distinguish between being 'risk averse' and upholding non-negotiable ethical or legal standards, especially when pressured by business units or external comparisons.

source_quotes.quoted_text: And navigating that ethical quandary and sort of demonstrating that this is not necessarily about risk tolerance. It's about, you know, what you like commitment to upholding the law. And sometimes I feel like that gets thrown into the mix as like, oh, we're being too risk averse. And I like to remind folks like, it is not risk averse to uphold your ethical obligation to comply with loss. Right. Um, and in, in moments there may be some stretch, there may be some interpretation, there may be some challenge, especially in unregulated areas. Right.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: I think the first thing I always do is assess a spectrum of risk. You know, like with respect to looking at crypto, I always say that there's three big areas of risk. One is kind of technical hack, um, integrity, like, or your smart contracts good. Is your code good? Like obviously there's massive issues. There is, are your privacy incident response areas great. You know, you don't mess with that because like, again, that's, that's pretty existential and easy to fill a gap. Two criminal also something you don't mess with. You know, do you have, uh, A-M-L-K-Y-C sanctions in place? If you don't, you better have a darn good reason why you don't. If you're dealing with flow of funds, like, is your position justi justifiable with respect to, you know, are you, you know, theoretically helping a flow of dirty money? And this could be considered a national security risk. Like how are you dealing with that? You need to have an answer to that, and it needs to be a very good one. The third one, regulatory, like civil regulators, cryptos, it's no, no, uh, no secret that cryptos parts of crypto are kind of at war with the SEC. Well, how, how is that? Okay. How can you be at war with your regulator, if not your current regulator, if your unregulated potentially your future regulator with respect to your posture with the CFTC or the SEC?
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

entries.question: For those of you at growth-stage companies who are actively building out your DEI programs, how are you leveraging data across the employee lifecycle (recruiting, hiring, retention, promotion) to identify problem areas and design interventions? Also, are you involving your legal team in both the strategic planning and day-to-day execution of these initiatives, and if so, what does that collaboration look like in practice? Would love to hear any real-world examples or lessons learned, especially from folks who have found ways to make these programs both effective and compliant as you scale.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The most effective diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) programs are data-driven, lifecycle-oriented, and involve legal in both strategic and operational roles. By analyzing recruiting, hiring, retention, and promotion data, organizations can identify bottlenecks and design targeted interventions, with legal teams playing a key role in ensuring fairness and compliance throughout the process.

source_quotes.quoted_text: And so what we did is we went and we looked at the data, uh, we looked at the data for our, our, our from hr. We looked at the data in our advertising, we looked at the data in pictures on our website, and we said, where are we falling off? How do we begin to address this holistically? And we started to ask these five questions. There are questions around recruiting, hiring, retaining, promoting, and measuring. And I'll go through these one by one. How do you attract a diverse set of candidates into your pipeline? One of the things we had to acknowledge was that our pipeline was unequal. We were attracting tons and tons of women. ... And we weren't really focusing on attracting different ages. We weren't really foc attract, um, focusing on attracting, um, people from different, um, racial and ethnic backgrounds. And we were realizing they were falling out of the pipeline at different points in the recruiting process. So how do we recruit more diversely? And we looked at the data and we were able to set up, um, areas of focus for different groups. So where do you focus? It's gonna vary from person to person, from company to company. It might even vary team to team. But you can look at your recruiting data and say, where are groups falling off and how can we focus our recruiting specifically to target different groups?
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

source_quotes.quoted_text: We reviewed our recruiting materials. We realized, like the first picture I opened up, you saw there's a picture of people crafting in hands. We realized a lot of our pictures, the hands were all white. What is that? That sense? A really strong message about who etsy's for. So we started looking at our recruiting materials, and we wanted to reflect the diversity of, of the culture. We, we, we wanted to build who's going to job fairs? We started asking that question, and we realized that the same two, um, people from HR were going to all the job fairs. They didn't represent, they didn't represent diversity, um, but they also didn't represent the diversity of the work in our, in our, in our company. And so we started inviting people from different areas, people, people who are engineers, people in hr, people in marketing. And we started presenting a more diverse portfolio of our employees.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Role of Legal in Building an Effective Diversity & Inclusion Program (Jill Simeone, Etsy)

entries.question: For those of you leading compliance or ethics training at mid-sized tech companies, have you found that incorporating real-world examples or case studies actually helps drive home key governance or policy lessons? If so, would love to hear any specific approaches or storytelling techniques that have worked well for your teams—especially when trying to make abstract principles resonate with a diverse audience. Thanks in advance for any insights!
entries.comprehensive_answer: A pattern across transcripts is the use of real-world examples, case studies, and storytelling as powerful tools for driving home ethical, compliance, and governance lessons. These narratives make abstract principles concrete, resonate with diverse audiences, and help bridge the gap between policy and practice.

source_quotes.quoted_text: But I actually feel this presentation chock full with real life ripped from the headlines. Examples of individual liability. Like, I think you need to speak about this in, in, you know, ways that your sales guy can understand. And if you're talking about regulatory issues or implications in a way that only lawyers will understand, it's really not gonna resonate. Where if you, you know, give them concrete examples of traders who have actually served prison time because of something stupid that they put in a chat like that is a lot more impactful.
source_quotes.transcript_title: The Art of Professionalism Navigating Ethical Conduct in Legal Practice

source_quotes.quoted_text: I, you know, I find it hard. I know you all find it hard because I think a lot of the times you've got to, you've gotta go to sort of horror stories. And this is what happens when things go badly and don't let this be you. And, you know, I never like to have to persuade that way because I think it's easy for people to, you know, distance themselves from that and believe it's not gonna be them. But, you know, I've seen the movie, I've seen how it ends that way. It ends that way for many companies. Um, you know, and one way or another turning negative. And, and you want to have had the right governance along the way to, before you get to that point.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

entries.question: For those at larger organizations, how are you approaching the management of sensitive information like legal advice, board materials, or client data—especially with the rise of digital communication and AI tools? Are you seeing a shift in protocols or tech (e.g., secure portals, anonymization, access controls) that’s working well, and what’s actually sticking in practice? Would love to hear what’s become standard in your shops and any lessons learned around keeping things secure without slowing down the business.
entries.comprehensive_answer: The responsible management of sensitive information—whether legal advice, board materials, or client data—requires secure systems, clear protocols, and ongoing vigilance. The use of secure portals, anonymization, and strict access controls is increasingly standard, especially as digital communication and AI tools proliferate.

source_quotes.quoted_text: one of the guardrails that my team, uh, is a bare minimum is that if we're using a public tool like chat GPT or anthropic to always, um, obs obfuscate the like client or the company information. So use Acme Co instead of Jasper. Uh, the tools like White Shoe and GC AI do this naturally. They like encrypt data in transit at rest and white shoe even like hashes it so that the LILM isn't even seeing like only the user's able to see it. Um, so those types of things get me comfortable that one, you're not sacrificing attorney-client privilege, but then two, like the only person who's ever gonna see the actual company information is, um, is yourself.
source_quotes.transcript_title: Prompting with Precision Leveraging AI Responsibly as In-House Counsel

source_quotes.quoted_text: Yeah, so Meredith, I I have a couple thoughts. I mean they're, in terms of which one to use, I think they're a bit fungible, but I actually like them for two particular reasons. One is the security of the information. So the ability to keep your important information behind some sort of secure system, not just email appeals to me, but I also think it's really valuable for folks in our seat in particular, right? It gives me a role where I get to step in and say, you know, we'll manage the portal, we'll manage the distribution material and everything goes to the board through that portal. It gives me a lot of, um, centralization of how information flows out and puts me in the middle of it, which I think is good from a governance perspective and also an information flow perspective. 'cause I know what's gonna be going in front of the board. So I, I think selfishly I like it for both those reasons.
source_quotes.transcript_title: TechGC Virtual Dinner Level Up Your Board(Jolie Siegel, C4 Therapeutics; Alan Smith & Kat Duncan, Fenwick)

Our finance team requires us to forecast spend for all OC vendors, and any unused budget at the end of a quarter is forfeited (i.e., it does not roll over). As a result, whenever we need to engage a new vendor or initiate a new matter mid-quarter, we're typically asked to reallocate funds from existing line items within our annual budget. Historically, this hasn't been a significant issue for us, but as our OC spend grows, it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage on an ad-hoc basis and as you know, it is impossible to anticipate all possible OC related spend ahead of time. I'm curious how others navigate this challenge. How do you plan for unpredictable legal spend? Do you build in contingency buffers, establish separate discretionary pools, or engage finance differently to accommodate real-time needs?
